resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

wesm commented on pull request #4049: ARROW-5029: [C++] Fix compilation warnings in release mode
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4049#discussion_r269763397
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/util/logging.h
 ##########
 @@ -81,22 +81,38 @@ enum class ArrowLogLevel : int {
 #ifdef NDEBUG
 #define ARROW_DFATAL ::arrow::util::ArrowLogLevel::ARROW_WARNING
 
-#define DCHECK(condition) \
+// CAUTION: DCHECK_OK() always evaluates its argument, but other DCHECK*() macros
+// only do so in debug mode.
+
+#define DCHECK(condition)                     \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(condition); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
 #define DCHECK_OK(s)    \
   ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(s); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_EQ(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_EQ(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_NE(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_NE(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_LE(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_LE(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_LT(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_LT(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_GE(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_GE(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_GT(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_GT(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
 
 Review comment:
   I'm not super keen on these changes. I would rather suppress the compiler warnings
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

 #ifdef NDEBUG
 #define ARROW_DFATAL ::arrow::util::ArrowLogLevel::ARROW_WARNING
 
-#define DCHECK(condition) \
+// CAUTION: DCHECK_OK() always evaluates its argument, but other DCHECK*() macros
+// only do so in debug mode.
+
+#define DCHECK(condition)                     \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(condition); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
 #define DCHECK_OK(s)    \
   ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(s); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_EQ(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_EQ(val1, val2)            \

+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_NE(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_NE(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_LE(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_LE(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_LT(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_LT(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_GE(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_GE(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
-#define DCHECK_GT(val1, val2) \
+#define DCHECK_GT(val1, val2)            \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1); \
+  while (false) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val2); \
   while (false) ::arrow::util::detail::NullLog()
 
 Review comment:
   You mean unconditionally? I'm not sure it's possible to suppress them selectively in the macro...

wesm commented on issue #4049: ARROW-5029: [C++] Fix compilation warnings in release mode
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4049#issuecomment-477355603
 
 
   I built on this branch without the changes to logging.h and things are OK:
   
   https://gist.github.com/wesm/d1a6a6e2a0b1e9f082b9fe14a98502d5
   
   Per my comments in https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4027, I think either we should
   
   * Add `ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(...)` statements to suppress warnings on a case-by-case basis rather than for every dcheck
   * Add `-Wno-unused-variable` in release builds (the "nuke it from orbit" approach)
   * Be OK with warnings associated with DCHECK statements in release builds 
   
   If we have actual unused variables, they'll show up in debug builds (right?). Part of why I'm unsure or opposed to these changes is that I've looked at other projects like glog and Kudu, and others that use similar DCHECK statements (ours originated from Apache Kudu) and they haven't deemed it necessary to make the changes made here or in https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4027 (I seem to recall one or two other PRs where we debated this)
   
   see e.g. glog https://github.com/google/glog/blob/master/src/glog/logging.h.in#L1034
   
   The DCHECK concept stems from glog so I don't think we should deviate significantly from what they are doing. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #4049: ARROW-5029: [C++] Fix compilation warnings in release mode
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4049#issuecomment-477356056
 
 
   In this case the warnings helped uncover the memory leaks. So I don't think it's a good idea to silence them unconditionally.
   
   I'm also unsure what we gain by silencing them one by one...
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4049#issuecomment-477357004
 
 
   If you look e.g. at `DLOG_IF(condition)`, the warning is silenced by the `(true || !(condition))` construct.

wesm commented on issue #4049: ARROW-5029: [C++] Fix compilation warnings in release mode
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4049#issuecomment-477359000
 
 
   Alright. I'll merge things as is with my uncertainty on the record. I guess I'm paranoid about compilers that might be bad at dead code elimination and so there could be executable bloat. Most modern compilers (gcc / clang) should delete these parts of the AST but who knows what MSVC will do =)
